Fukomys damarensis, commonly known as the Damaraland mole-rat, is a species of rodent belonging to the family Bathyergidae. It is a burrowing, subterranean mammal found in southern Africa, primarily in Namibia and Botswana.

The Damaraland mole-rat is a medium-sized, stocky rodent with a large head, small eyes, and short, rounded ears. Its fur is soft and dense, typically ranging in color from grayish-brown to reddish-brown. They have robust, clawed forelimbs adapted for digging and burrowing through the soil.

These mole-rats are eusocial, living in colonies with a single breeding pair and a hierarchy of non-breeding individuals. They are herbivorous, feeding on roots, tubers, and other underground plant materials. Their burrow systems can be extensive, with multiple chambers and tunnels used for nesting, food storage, and waste disposal.

Fukomys damarensis is well-adapted to the arid and semi-arid environments of southern Africa, with physiological mechanisms to conserve water and thermoregulate in the challenging desert conditions. They play an important role in the ecosystem, contributing to soil aeration, nutrient cycling, and the distribution of plant resources.
